title: Investigation into suspected vandalism at Education Department concludes that incident was an accident
text:
The Federal Protective Service, an arm of the Homeland Security Department, and the Education Department’s inspector general conducted a joint investigation with the same conclusion: The poster fell and damaged the items.

AD

Investigators briefed Education Department employees Tuesday, detailing interviews with staff and records on everyone’s whereabouts at the time of the incident, said Education Department spokeswoman Angela Morabito. The Federal Protective Service and the inspector general did not respond to a request for comment Tuesday evening.

AD

“There is no reason to believe it was a personal attack. … [The poster] just fell off the wall,” Morabito said. The incident “was so disturbing to everybody here. It came out of left field … but we weren’t able to say anything for sure until the investigation happened.”

The incident was first reported by NBC News, which said staffers at the Education Department suspected the alleged vandalism was racially motivated. At the time, the department declined to comment on specifics because of the investigation. The agency said the employee was part of the diversity change agency program that trains employees to “foster more inclusive workplaces.”

AD

An agency-wide email sent after the incident came to light alerted employees to the episode and directed people with knowledge to contact security.

“This cowardly action is intolerable and unacceptable,” said the email, which was sent from an official in the department’s Office of Finance and Operations.

“Your security at work should never be a concern,” the letter continued. “Every leader in this building is ready to listen and help should you have any issues or suggestions.”

AD
description: Two months after the agency began investigating an apparent act of vandalism, a joint investigation has concluded the incident was an accident.
authors: Reporter Covering The Economics Of Education
